meanings.def: costing little money or less money than you expected
examples: cheap imports/flights
Their cheap prices have helped them pick up new customers.
They're offering incredibly cheap fares to Eastern Europe.
Cycling is a cheap way to get around.
A good education is not cheap.
Electricity is relatively cheap in Ireland.
The device isn't exactly cheap at £500.
A falling dollar will boost the economy by making exports cheaper.
a cheaper alternative/option
Renewable energy is getting cheaper all the time.
The cheapest rates are usually available online.
These desperate people are used as a source of cheap labour (= workers who are paid very little, especially unfairly).
cheap to do Game shows are cheap to produce.
it is cheap to do something Why go by train when it's so cheap to hop on a plane?
The market has been flooded with cheap imports.
The printer isn't exactly cheap at £200.
The town is full of immigrant workers, used as a source of cheap labour.
The watch was suspiciously cheap; it was probably a fake.
a cheap restaurant/hotel
a cheap taxi firm
(British English) We found a cheap and cheerful cafe (= one that is simple and charges low prices but is pleasant).
It's a good restaurant, and incredibly cheap.
Italy was a very cheap country to visit in those days.
cheap perfume/jewellery/shoes
cheap plastic toys that break within seconds
(British English) a cheap and nasty bottle of wine
cheap and nasty products with brand names you've never heard of
The room was filled with the smell of cheap perfume.
It was just a bottle of cheap perfume.
The bag looks cheap and nasty.
The glasses are plain without looking cheap.

meanings.def: unpleasant or unkind and rather obvious
examples: I was tired of his cheap jokes at my expense.
a comedian who is always looking for cheap laughs
to score a cheap political advantage
He couldn't resist taking a cheap shot at his political opponent.

meanings.def: having a low status and therefore not deserving respect
examples: He's just a cheap crook.
His treatment of her made her feel cheap (= ashamed, because she had lost her respect for herself).
Don't be so cheap!
He's so cheap, he'd never fly to London in a million years.
She was just too cheap to buy a real present.
He was so generous he made the other guests look cheap.

meanings.def: so good or useful that the cost does not seem too much
examples: To buy all the recommended equipment is expensive, but as an investment for the future it is cheap at the price.

meanings.def: used to say that there is a situation in which it is not thought to be important if people somewhere die or are treated badly
spending less money than you usually need to spend to do something
examples: a guide to decorating your house on the cheap
to acquire valuable works of art on the cheap
The school managed to get a couple of computers on the cheap.

idioms.def: so good or useful that the cost does not seem too much
examples: To buy all the recommended equipment is expensive, but as an investment for the future it is cheap at the price.

idioms.def: used to say that there is a situation in which it is not thought to be important if people somewhere die or are treated badly
spending less money than you usually need to spend to do something
examples: a guide to decorating your house on the cheap
to acquire valuable works of art on the cheap
The school managed to get a couple of computers on the cheap.
I got this dress cheap in a sale.
You can buy it cheaper elsewhere.
They're selling fabrics cheap this week.
Two people can live cheaper than one.
private equity companies that borrow cheap

meanings.def: to be offered for sale at a lower price than usual
examples: The house was going cheap because the owner wanted a quick sale.
There was usually some bread going cheap at the end of the day.
Violins like this don't come cheap.
A quality pair of Italian shoes doesn't come cheap.

idioms.def: to be offered for sale at a lower price than usual
examples: The house was going cheap because the owner wanted a quick sale.
There was usually some bread going cheap at the end of the day.
Violins like this don't come cheap.
A quality pair of Italian shoes doesn't come cheap.
